Symptoms: Sore throat, Runny nose, Cough, Hoarseness, Low-grade fever, Body aches
Description: Viral pharyngitis is the inflammation of the pharynx caused by a viral infection, commonly due to rhinovirus, influenza, Epstein-Barr virus (mononucleosis), or COVID-19.
Treatment: Symptomatic relief: Rest, hydration, warm salt water gargles, lozenges, acetaminophen or ibuprofen. Antibiotics are not effective.
Risk_Factors: Exposure to viral infections, close contact with sick individuals, weakened immune system, seasonal changes.

Symptoms: Severe sore throat, Fever, Swollen lymph nodes, Red and swollen tonsils, White patches on tonsils, Headache
Description: A bacterial infection of the throat and tonsils caused by group A Streptococcus. Unlike viral pharyngitis, it often lacks cough or runny nose.
Treatment: Antibiotics (penicillin or amoxicillin), rest, hydration, pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen.
Risk_Factors: Close contact with infected individuals, children aged 5–15, overcrowded environments, poor hygiene.

Symptoms: Extreme fatigue, Sore throat, Swollen lymph nodes, Fever, Enlarged spleen, Rash
Description: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, mononucleosis is a contagious infection that typically spreads via saliva.
Treatment: Rest, hydration, avoiding contact sports (if spleen enlarged), pain and fever management. No specific antiviral.
Risk_Factors: Teenagers and young adults, kissing or sharing drinks, weakened immunity.

Symptoms: fever, joint pain, muscle pain, headache, rash, fatigue
Description: Chikungunya is a viral illness transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. It causes sudden onset of fever and severe joint pain, often accompanied by muscle pain, rash, and fatigue.
Treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment. Supportive care includes rest, hydration, and use of acetaminophen or paracetamol to reduce fever and pain. NSAIDs should be avoided until dengue is ruled out.
Risk_Factors: Living or traveling in mosquito-prone regions, exposure to daytime-biting mosquitoes (Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus), and lack of mosquito control.

Symptoms: high fever, headache, pain behind the eyes, joint pain, muscle pain, skin rash, mild bleeding, fatigue
Description: Dengue Fever is a mosquito-borne viral infection common in tropical and subtropical regions. It presents with flu-like symptoms and, in severe cases, can lead to dengue hemorrhagic fever.
Treatment: No specific antiviral treatment. Management includes supportive care with fluids, rest, and acetaminophen for pain and fever. NSAIDs and aspirin should be avoided due to bleeding risk.
Risk_Factors: Living or traveling in tropical/subtropical areas, previous dengue infection, poor sanitation, and mosquito breeding sites such as standing water.

Symptoms: diarrhea, vomiting, nausea, abdominal cramps, fever, headache, muscle aches
Description: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines caused by a viral infection (e.g., norovirus, rotavirus), commonly known as the stomach flu. It is highly contagious.
Treatment: Supportive care focusing on rehydration with fluids and electrolytes (oral rehydration solution), rest, and a bland diet (BRAT). Antiemetics or antidiarrheals may be used under medical supervision.
Risk_Factors: Consumption of contaminated food or water, close contact with an infected person, poor hygiene, being in crowded environments like daycares or cruise ships.
